metadata.context: Designed for non-specialist providers in conflict-affected settings

depression.name: Depression
symptoms: sleep problems (too much or too little)
immediate_support: listen without judgment
ask directly about suicidal thoughts
encourage daily routine and physical activity
help identify trusted support person
avoid saying 'just be strong' or 'others have it worse'
when_to_refer: unable to function at home or work
coping_strategies: maintain regular sleep schedule
do one small activity each day
stay connected with family and community
avoid alcohol as a coping mechanism
gentle physical activity like walking

ptsd.name: Post-Traumatic Stress
symptoms: feeling on edge or easily startled
difficulty remembering parts of what happened
danger_signs: using alcohol or drugs to cope
immediate_support: provide calm, safe environment
use grounding techniques during flashbacks
validate their experience - 'what you feel is normal'
help identify triggers and safe places
do not pressure to talk about trauma
when_to_refer: unable to care for children or self
coping_strategies: grounding: name 5 things you see, 4 you hear, 3 you feel
slow breathing: 4 counts in, 4 counts out
remind yourself: 'I am safe now, that was the past'
talk to trusted person when ready
gentle daily routine helps healing

anxiety.name: Anxiety
danger_signs: panic attacks that feel like heart attack
not leaving home due to fear
immediate_support: help with slow breathing exercise
provide reassurance - 'these feelings will pass'
help identify specific worries
encourage small steps, not avoidance
limit excessive news or triggering information
coping_strategies: slow breathing: breathe in 4 counts, out 6 counts
progressive muscle relaxation
limit coffee and stimulants
regular physical activity
talk about worries with trusted person

grief.name: Grief and Loss
symptoms: anger at self, others, or God
danger_signs: suicidal thoughts to 'be with' the person
immediate_support: be present and listen
acknowledge the loss - 'I am sorry for your loss'
allow expression of emotions without judgment
help with practical needs if appropriate
do not say 'be strong' or 'move on'
when_to_refer: grief preventing all functioning after 6 months
coping_strategies: allow yourself to grieve - there is no timeline
talk about the person when you want to
maintain cultural and religious mourning practices
accept help from community
take care of basic needs: eat, sleep, move

acute_stress.name: Acute Stress Response
symptoms: shock or disbelief immediately after event
immediate_support: ensure physical safety first
provide calm, quiet environment
offer practical help (water, food, blanket)
listen if they want to talk, do not force
help connect to family or support
when_to_refer: symptoms severe or worsening after 3 days
coping_strategies: focus on immediate safety and basic needs
slow breathing when overwhelmed
stay with trusted people
limit exposure to traumatic reminders
symptoms often improve naturally in days to weeks

sexual_trauma.name: Genocidal Sexual Violence
sexual_trauma.context: Sexual violence in Tigray was used systematically as a weapon of genocide - targeting women specifically because they are Tigrayan. Over 120,000 documented cases, estimated 500,000+ total. 80%+ were gang rapes. 90% of survivors receive no support. This was not random violence - perpetrators explicitly stated intent to 'cleanse Tigrayan blood' and destroy reproductive capacity.

scale_of_violence.prevalence: 1 in 10 women in Tigray subjected to sexual violence

perpetrator_statements_survivors_heard: We will make you give birth to Amhara/Eritrean children
Tigrayans have no history and culture
You will never give birth to a Tigrayan again
We want to destroy your identity
This is what you deserve as a Tigrayan
symptoms: flashbacks that feel 'fresh and vivid' even a year later
feeling like 'head is about to explode'
avoiding people, places, or situations that remind of assault
feelings of shame about 'secret being exposed' - often worse than assault itself
physical symptoms: vaginal bleeding for months, fistulas, broken teeth
danger_signs: not eating, drinking, or caring for self
signs of physical injury needing medical care
HIV symptoms (PEP must be started within 72 hours)
immediate_support: BELIEVE them - say 'I believe you. This was not your fault.'
acknowledge the ethnic dimension: 'They targeted you because you are Tigrayan - this was genocide'
let them control the conversation - do not pressure for details
respect their choices about reporting or not reporting
ensure physical safety and privacy
offer practical support without conditions
maintain strict confidentiality
validate their identity: 'Your identity was not destroyed by what they did'
do_not: do not ask 'why didn't you fight back'
do not ask about clothing or location
do not ask about ethnicity of perpetrators initially
do not say 'at least you survived'
do not ask if she became pregnant
do not pressure to report - 80%+ did not report within 72 hours
do not tell others without explicit permission
do not compare traumas ('others had it worse')
do not treat children born of rape differently
do not suggest forgiveness before they are ready
when_to_refer: risk of pregnancy - medical care needed
HIV exposure - PEP must start within 72 hours
coping_strategies: healing takes time - there is no 'right' timeline
you are not to blame for what happened to you
grounding techniques help during flashbacks: name 5 things you see, 4 you hear, 3 you feel
choose who to tell and when - you control your story
physical safety planning if perpetrator is known
connect with other survivors when ready - you are not alone
self-care: sleep, eating, gentle movement
reclaiming identity: speaking Tigrinya, practicing culture = resistance

emergency_timeline.pep_for_hiv: Must start within 72 hours of assault
emergency_timeline.pregnancy_testing: When ready, typically after missed period

ongoing_care: vaginal bleeding may persist for months - seek care
fistula repair surgery may be needed

ethnic_identity_healing: Your identity was not destroyed by what they did
Your survival resists their attempt to erase Tigrayans
Speaking Tigrinya, practicing culture = reclaiming what they tried to take
Community solidarity is part of healing
They wanted to destroy your people - your existence is resistance
sexual_trauma.triple_trauma_burden: 76.5% of survivors experienced sexual + physical + psychological trauma combined

pregnancy_from_rape.name: Pregnancy from Sexual Violence
pregnancy_from_rape.context: Pregnancy resulting from genocidal rape carries unique trauma - perpetrators explicitly intended to impregnate Tigrayan women with 'enemy' children. Whatever a survivor decides about the pregnancy is HER choice.
validation: This pregnancy does not define you
Whatever you decide is YOUR choice
Complex feelings are normal - there is no 'right' way to feel
You did nothing wrong - this was done TO you
Feeling conflicted about this pregnancy is completely understandable

immediate: Emergency contraception: effective within 72-120 hours of assault
Pregnancy testing when you are ready
choices: All options are valid choices that only YOU can make
Continue pregnancy and raise the child
Terminate pregnancy if accessible and desired
Medical care is available without judgment for any choice

if_continuing_pregnancy: You deserve prenatal care and support without judgment
The child is innocent of how they were conceived
Complex feelings toward the pregnancy are completely normal
You can love this child AND grieve what happened - both are true
Bonding may take time - this is normal after trauma
You do not owe anyone an explanation about the father
stigma_you_may_face: Some husbands abandon wives who were raped - this is THEIR moral failure, not yours
Some communities reject survivors - they are wrong
You did nothing to deserve this treatment
Seeking support is strength, not shame
The shame belongs to perpetrators, not survivors
support_needs: economic support - many survivors lost everything
safe housing if rejected by family
long-term follow-up for mother and child

children_born_of_rape.name: Children Born of Sexual Violence
children_born_of_rape.context: In Tigray, children born from genocidal rape face unique challenges. Research from Rwanda shows that mother-child relationships can heal with proper support. These children are victims too and deserve full community inclusion.
for_mothers: Complex feelings (love, resentment, grief) are ALL normal
Seeing perpetrator's features in child can trigger flashbacks - this is trauma, not failure as a mother
You can love your child AND hate how they were conceived
Open communication (when age-appropriate) helps healing - Rwanda research shows this
Economic support is critical - seek help without shame
Bonding may take time and that is okay
Getting support for yourself helps you support your child
for_community_helpers: These children are victims too - never blame them
Never call them 'rape babies' or 'children of the enemy'
Boys often face more stigma (seen as 'potential criminals like fathers') - this is wrong and harmful
Both mother and child need long-term support, not one-time assistance
Include these families fully in community activities
Challenge stigmatizing language when you hear it
for_the_children: How you were conceived does not define who you are
You are not your biological father
Your mother's love for you is real, even if complicated
You deserve full community inclusion and recognition
Your identity is Tigrayan - no one can take that from you
You have the right to know your story when you are ready
identity_development: Children may ask about their fathers - prepare honest, age-appropriate answers
Tigrayan identity can be affirmed regardless of biological father
Community acceptance is crucial for healthy identity
Counseling support for both mother and child as child grows

hal_circles.name: HAL Circles (Helpful Active Listening)
hal_circles.origin: Developed after Rwanda genocide, successfully adapted for Tigray by survivor-facilitators
how_it_works: Facilitators are survivors themselves (trained for 5 days)
6 sessions over 3 months, approximately 3 hours each
Focus on understanding trauma RESPONSES, NOT retelling assault details
Uses cultural metaphors (e.g., 'bent stick' for psychological breaking)
Sessions held in safe, private community spaces
key_principles: You are not alone - the core message
Trauma responses are NORMAL reactions to abnormal events
Peer support from those who truly understand
No pressure to share details of what happened
Regaining sense of control and agency
what_helps: Knowing you are not alone in your experiences
Learning that trauma responses (flashbacks, nightmares, shame) are NORMAL
Peer support from those who truly understand without explanation
Regaining sense of control over your own story
outcomes: Restored sense of hope and future

cultural_metaphors_used.bent_stick: Psychological breaking that can be straightened with care
cultural_metaphors_used.community_fire: Healing warmth that comes from gathering together
cultural_metaphors_used.shared_water: Tears and stories that flow between survivors

suicidal_thoughts.name: Suicide Risk
recognition: talking about wanting to die or kill self
looking for ways to harm self
talking about being a burden to others
feeling hopeless or having no reason to live
immediate_action: take all talk of suicide seriously
ask directly: 'Are you thinking of hurting yourself?'
listen without judgment
do not leave person alone if immediate risk
remove access to means (weapons, pills, rope)
help create safety plan with trusted contacts
connect to professional help urgently
do_not: do not promise to keep suicidal plans secret
do not leave high-risk person alone
do not challenge or dare them
safety_planning: identify warning signs person notices in self
identify 2-3 people to contact for support
remove or secure means of self-harm

panic_attack.name: Panic Attack
recognition: fear of dying or losing control
immediate_action: stay calm and speak slowly
reassure: 'This will pass, you are safe'
guide slow breathing: in for 4, out for 6
use grounding: 'tell me 5 things you see'
stay with person until symptoms reduce
do not dismiss or minimize experience
after_care: discuss what may have triggered it
refer if panic attacks are frequent

dissociation.name: Dissociation/Flashback
recognition: staring blankly, not aware of surroundings
immediate_action: speak calmly using their name
use grounding: 'You are safe. You are in [location]'
ask to describe room: colors, objects
encourage slow breathing
ask to feel feet on floor, hands on chair
do not touch without permission
stay present until they return to awareness

look: check for safety and ongoing threats
observe basic needs: shelter, food, water
listen: help person feel calm using grounding
do not pressure to talk about what happened
link: help access basic needs (food, water, shelter)
connect to family and social support
link to professional help if needed
do_not_do: do not force people to share their story
do not make promises you cannot keep
do not tell them how they should feel
do not give simple reassurances like 'it will be fine'
do not tell your own story instead of listening

grounding_techniques.name: Grounding (For Flashbacks/Panic)
physical_grounding: hold an ice cube or cold water

breathing_exercises.name: Breathing Exercises
slow_breathing: breathe in slowly through nose for 4 counts
breathe out slowly through mouth for 6 counts
belly_breathing: place one hand on chest, one on belly
breathe in so belly rises (not chest)

social_connection.name: Social Connection
strategies: identify 2-3 trusted people to talk to
spend time with family even if quiet
participate in community or religious activities
help others as able - helping heals
avoid isolation even when wanting to withdraw

daily_routine.name: Daily Routine
elements: wake at consistent time each day
eat regular meals even if small

common_myths: mental illness is a sign of weakness
people with mental illness are dangerous
mental illness is caused by spirits or curses
depression means you are not faithful enough
talking about suicide gives people ideas
children cannot have mental health problems
sexual_violence_myths: MYTH: She could have prevented it if she fought harder
FACT: Freeze response is a normal survival mechanism - many cannot fight or flee
MYTH: She brought it on herself by her clothing or behavior
FACT: Rape is about power and violence, not attraction. Perpetrators chose to attack.
MYTH: A 'good' woman would die rather than be raped
FACT: Survival is strength. Living to tell the story is resistance.
MYTH: If she became pregnant, she must have enjoyed it
FACT: Pregnancy is a biological response that can occur during any sexual act, including violent assault
MYTH: Children born of rape carry the father's evil
FACT: Children are innocent of how they were conceived. They are victims too.
facts: mental illness is a medical condition like diabetes
1 in 4 people experience mental health problems
treatment helps most people recover or improve
mental illness affects all families, all communities
trauma can affect anyone - it is not weakness
asking about suicide reduces risk, does not increase it
rape survivors did nothing to cause their assault
seeking help after trauma is strength, not shame
how_to_talk: share that seeking help shows strength
how_to_support_rape_survivors: believe them - do not question their account
say 'I believe you. This was not your fault.'
do not ask for details of the assault
do not tell them to forgive before they are ready
community_approach: create safe spaces to discuss struggles
welcome survivors and their children back into community
challenge stigmatizing language about rape survivors

symptoms_different: changes in play or school performance
support_strategies: maintain routines as much as possible
allow expression through play and drawing

key_considerations: do not pressure to report if not ready
support_approach: connect to specialized services if available

self_care: you cannot help others if depleted

local_resources.note: Resources for Tigray region mental health and sexual violence support

medical: health centers can provide PEP (HIV prevention) - must start within 72 hours
fistula repair available at some hospitals
psychosocial: HAL Circles - peer support groups for survivors (ask at health centers)
community health workers trained in PFA
women's associations may have support programs
practical: legal aid for those who choose to report

general_guidance: health centers may have mental health services
community health workers can provide first support
peer support from others with similar experiences
HAL Circles specifically for sexual violence survivors
when_professional_needed: unable to care for self or dependents

key_organizations.unfpa: UN Population Fund - sexual violence response
key_organizations.who: World Health Organization - mental health guidelines
